Description: Grey-brown pottery pilgrim-flask with circular body. On each side, within a border of studs, Saint Menas stands to front, his arms outstretched in blessing. Above each arm is a cross. He has curly hair, wears a short tunic and a long cloak, and is flanked by camels. Both sides are from moulds produced from the same archetype. The mouth and handles are largely missing.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased from Selima Harris, collector, a resident of Alexandria and daughter of the collector and dealer Anthony C. Harris. Late Roman, about AD 480-650. Comparanda: Close: Abd el-Fattah 2001: 37, fig. 2.42 and 43, from Gabbari, Alexandria; Bagnall and Rathbone 2004: 118; Kiss 1989a: nos 51, 52, 57 (fig. 94) and 62 from Kom el-Dikka, Alexandria, context of AD 610-650; Lunsingh Scheurleer 1998: 3, fig. 4, bottom right; Metzger 1981: no. 10, dated sixth to seventh century AD; Witt 2000: no. 9, from Alexandria, and no. 15, dated end of fifth to mid-seventh century AD. Near: Ashmolean Museum, Oxford, no. 1872.492, acquired by the vendor in Alexandria; Petrie Museum uc65098.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3416)
Condition: fair (neck damaged and both handles missing)
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: BS.5232.j (Birch Slip Number not extant)
